# What is EMA? {#intro}

\index{EMA} 
\index{EMA!Synonymns} 
\index{Ambulatory Assesment|see{EMA!Synonymns}} 
\index{Experience Sampling|see{EMA!Synonymns}} 
\index{continuous unified electronic diary method|see{EMA!Synonymns}}

Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) has many aliases. It is known as the
experience sampling method [@Larson1983], ambulatory assessment [@EbnerPriemer2009] or Ambulatory self-report [@Conner2012], real-time data capturing,
the continuous unified electronic diary method [@EllisDavies2012], and as
the intensive-longitudinal study design [@Bolger2013]. All these terms refer
to research methods that involve the repeated sampling of people's current
thoughts, emotions, behaviour, physiological states, and context, in their
natural environment, typically (but not necessary) via electronic wearable
devices [@Shiffman2008].

## Why EMA?

EMA aims to "minimize recall bias, maximize ecological validity, and
allow study of microprocesses that influence behavior in real-world
contexts." [@Shiffman2008].

# simulate individual
sim_p <- function(id = 1, intercept = 0, x_start = 0){
  x = (0:9)
  y = intercept + x * .9 + rnorm(10, 0, 1.5)
  data.frame(id = id, x = x + x_start, y = y)
}

# define effeft of x on y for the group
intercept = 100
x = seq(1, 100, 10)
y = 100 - .4 * x 

# let individuals define the group
dt = NULL
for(i in 1:10) {
  p = sim_p(i, y[i], x[i])
  dt = rbind(dt, p)
}

ggplot(dt, aes(x = x, y = y, group = id)) + 
  geom_point(size = 1, shape = 16) + 
  stat_ellipse(color = "black", level = .99, type = "t") + 
  stat_ellipse(color = "black", level = .99, aes(group = NULL)) +
  theme_bw(12) + 
  theme(axis.text=element_blank(),
        axis.ticks=element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
        panel.background = element_blank())
